usa: The Congress of Racial Equality was established.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference">[180]</sup>
The Office of Price Administration was established.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference">[181]</sup>
Automobile production in the United States for private consumers is halted by the War Production Board.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference">[182]</sup>
Japanese American internment: Internment and seizure of property began, per Executive Order 9066 issued by President Roosevelt.[183]

The U.S. surrenders to Japan in the Battle of Bataan, beginning the three-year occupation of the Commonwealth of the Philippines by Japanese forces.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference">[184]</sup>
President Roosevelt signed Executive order 8734; establishing the Office of Price Administration.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference">[185]</sup>
Pacific Theater of Operations: The Doolittle Raid begins the first U.S. bombing of Japanese archipelago.[186]
The Aleutian Islands Campaign begins the Japanese occupation of Alaska Territory.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference">[187]</sup>
The Battle of Midway was fought.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference">[188]</sup>
The Guadalcanal Campaign begins in the Solomon Islands.[189]
The Manhattan Project, leading to the development of the first atomic bomb, began.[190]
The Revenue Act of 1942 was signed into law.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference">[191]</sup>
The Cocoanut Grove fire, the deadliest nightclub fire in U.S. history, killed 492 people in Boston.[192]
